title: Mining Mobile Source Emissiona and Activity Data

author: Eugene Tierney, US Environmental Protection Agency

segmentation: OK, thank you very much.

I'm with the Office of Transportation and Air Quality at EPA and I'm going to talk about the work that we've been doing over the last 40 years, really to collect data and analyze it and use it to make decisions about how to manage era air quality throughout the United States.
Let's say.
We have a laboratory in Ann Arbor, MI.
The National vehicle Fuel Emissions Laboratory, which was was built back in the early 70s.
We over the years have used that laboratory to recruit.
Motor vehicles, trucks.
An nonroad equipment and test it for emissions, fuel consumption, and so on and so forth.
An for the most part.
Up until recently, we have done that emission testing work using what we call the federal test procedure.
There are different test procedures for different types of equipment, cars versus trucks versus non red equipment.
But basically we're talking about a specified driving cycle.
Running a laboratory under highly controlled conditions in you know, very repeatable and accurate way and.
A lot of this testing has evolved over the years as a tool for EPA to implement the regulations that we impose on vehicle and engine manufacturers in which we require them to meet emission standards.

So those are very standardized test procedures that all engine manufacturers throughout the world that either that export to the United States are quite familiar with as well as our domestic manufacturers.
And we also go out and we borrow vehicles and engines from owners once they are in use and test them as well.
And the problems that we've encountered doing this or that, you know, getting getting a car into the laboratory is not too hard.
You can give somebody a rental car.
You can give us some money for as an incentive, and they'll loan you their car for a couple of days so that you can test it and see how it's performing on the road.
But doing that with a bulldozer is a whole different story, and it's extremely difficult.
It's extremely expensive.
The next problem is the laboratory.
Testing doesn't really reflect what's going on in the real world, you know, as a shock was just saying, you know, we want to know what's going on almost on an instantaneous basis.
What's going on with vehicles that are on the road today?
Given the current state of fuels, the current temperature, etc etc, etc.
And you know, in the laboratory we control the temperature.
We can.
The driver who drives a car has a lot of impact on how much emissions, how much fuel gets burned in the chorus of any given driving cycle.

In fact, one of the car manufacturers would come and they would hope that certain drivers would be testing their car during the certification process because they they, you know, less throttle dithering.

Fuel of course has a big impact on emissions and then all the other things that go on in the environment like the you know, the road grade, the quality of the road, how much you know, what speed you're going, how much acceleration, deceleration and so on and so forth.
So all these factors influence real world emissions that aren't.
Adequately caught in laboratory situation.
So about 10 years ago I got involved in working with industry to develop a new approach.
I became the head of the modeling section of the Office of Transportation and Air Quality, in which we.
You know, take the data that we collect.
We put it into a model and we use those models to represent the emissions that are happening out there in the world, at least in the United States.

So what we've done is we've developed with the help of Industry 2 new technologies that I call pens and Pams, Pams are portable emission measurement systems, basically took the laboratory that we used to test cars and other equipment we put in a box.
And I'll show you a picture in a minute.
It measures all the critical pollutants of interest as well as all of the activity and other kinds of parameters that are of interest in terms of understanding what's going on with motor vehicles.

Similarly we we pushed industry to develop what we call pans, which were portable activity monitoring systems, which is essentially similar, but it doesn't do the emission testing, so it's smaller, cheaper and more easily deployed.
Here's a few pictures of pens and Pams.
The The blue box over there is about a 70 pound device you put in the trunk of a car attached to the tailpipe.
Attach it to the onboard diagnostic system and you can capture all the emissions of vehicle in real time as it's driven around.
The the device over here is a similar technology, but it also captures Particule.
It matter of diesel trucks, the small device down in the bottom corner is the Pams.
It's just a portable activity monitor.
You hook it up to the onboard diagnostic system on the car or the truck and you can capture scads of data over very long periods of time about activity and how the vehicle is being used.
The Pens and Pam's are much shorter duration.
More like, you know, a day or two or three, and they need a lot of care and feeding.
Whereas Pam's you can put him on a car and forget about.
For awhile, here's here's a couple of illustrations of deployment of pens in the trunk of a car attached to the tailpipe.
Paint pens on top of a bulldozer.
Capturing the missions in real time, why do we care about this?
Well, as I said before.
Wrapped by the.
Triangle here.
This is acceleration with 0 being in the middle, negative and positive acceleration going across the axis speed and emissions of carbon monoxide.
This is just an example.
As you can see the test that we used to certify vehicles in the laboratory to make sure that the manufacturers are building them according to our standards are represented by this speed and activity.
Notice that all of the emissions occur outside of that range.
OK, this was when I first when we first this was early data.
This is about 10 years old.
Now when we first showed this chart to our bosses in the lab, they were like.
Oh my God.
Was revolutionary so.
What we've done is we've gone from this, you know, standard driving cycle to going out into the rear.

Real world capturing data on vehicles as they are being driven by regular people by truck drivers etc etc and then using that data to create our estimates of how much emissions are being generated by mobile sources in the real world.
And to facilitate that, we've we've come up with a new model which is called.
It just came out in final form.
It's called moves 2010.
You know our previous model, Mobile 6.
Some of you may be familiar with it was a was a Fortran based model built back in the 1970s.
We had been modifying and modifying and modifying.
When I took over, I said we can't even hire Fortran programmers.
We gotta stop this.
So we built a new model.
It's basically it's a my SQL database which takes all of this wonderful data that we can capture out there using pens and Pams.
Crunches it down to something manageable and that's the challenge.

And puts it, you know, a Java GUI interface on top of it so that you can go in and do all kinds of analysis that we could never do before I threw up the equation just to prove that I'm a scientist, I threw up the equation that we use all of the emissions are based on today now on vehicle specific power.
Before we had one number, for example, hydrocarbon emissions for that entire driving cycle, that 20 minute driving cycle.
That the FTP represents one number for 20 minutes of driving all different speeds blah blah blah.
Not a very useful piece of information.
Now we have second by second information converted into vehicle specific power which captures sort of the critical elements of what's going on with the vehicle.
Here's an example of carbon dioxide emissions.
By vehicle specific power.
Been as you go up across the axis here, more and more power, more and more missions.
Second by second data with with the air conditioner on versus off.
Data that we could never get before turns out air conditioning use is very critical to me.
Another source of information that we're starting to move into is what I call remote OBD more and more.
Vehicles today are originally equipped with telematics devices like GM's, OnStar and.
Aftermarket devices are available and being used on.
That's my 10 minutes.
This is my last slide are being used on vehicles and you can capture enormous quantities of information.
You know a lot of you are probably familiar with vehicle inspection and maintenance programs where you have to go in and get your car tested every year too.
With remote OBD with these devices on cars you don't even have to show up.
Your car can be continuously monitored.
We can.
Better manage the results, get more emission reduction benefits, so we're working with industry right now to develop a national protocol and guidance for states to implement such programs.
So the challenges that we are facing now is now we can go out with these portable emission measurement systems.
The Pams remote OBD collect massive quantities of data and we struggle.
Of course to do the analysis to figure out what do you do with all this data.
There's a lot to be gotten out of this information, and we are just barely scratching the surface at this point.
And with that I'll turn it over to our.
